In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the Julia code to solve your problem:
```julia
function wrap_string(s::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = "$word"
        else
            line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    return result * "\n" * line
end
```
This function works by splitting the input string into words, then iterating over each word. If adding a new word to the current line would exceed the maximum `text_width`, it starts a new line and adds the current word to that line. Otherwise, it just adds the word to the current line. At the end of the function, it concatenates any remaining words on the last line.

Here is an example usage:
```julia
print(wrap_string("Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit", 15))
```
This will print:
```
Lorem ipsum
dolor sit amet,
consectetur
adipiscing elit
```
